NO child can grow up around so many books and NOT turn into an original thinker and extraordinary writerâ€¦

This is my home library in Mumbai (minus the 500+ books we have given away over the years.)

Growing up, Iâ€™ve seen my dad read a new book EVERY SINGLE DAY, for years. He would sit for 3-4 hours at a stretch with a pencil in one hand, and finish reading the book cover-to-cover.

Classics, history, historical fiction, anatomy, business, sci-fi, poetry - you name it, he has read it.

While staring at the shelf last night, I realised: I understand now that having books in the house is a must.

It is the duty of parents to bring tons of books into the house every year.

It is the duty of parents to read new books in front of their children and set a good example, without having to force their children to read.

It is the duty of parents to spark conversations about their new learnings at the dinner table daily.

Itâ€™s the duty of parents to buy books for their children - even if they donâ€™t read them yet. Buy them a variety over time and let them discover their interests by trial and error.

As a final note:

I have read barely 5 books from my dadâ€™s collection.

But what I HAVE done over the years is: Flipped through most of these books and read a few pages of whichever part caught my attention.

This random habit has - subconsciously- had a huge influence on my writing style, skills, ideas and interests.

May more kids grow up with books around them â¤ï¸

#ShreyaWrites

What if motivation and discipline, both, fail?

There's something strange about returning to work after a long Diwali weekend. At this point, not only is the month almost over, but the year is also almost over... and our goals start getting pushed to the 1st of January.

The motivation to get things done tends to fade away slowly...

And that's when discipline comes in.

In fact, I've always said that discipline >>> motivation. You do what you've got to do regardless of how you feel about it, and you keep things moving. Simple.

But, what if discipline fails too?

What if you're just not able to get yourself to move?

What if nothing feels right and any action feels worthless?

What if you feel it's easier to give up on your goals than it is to put in the work towards achieving it?

What then?

What do you do when motivation and discipline, both, FAIL?

Then, you rely on this secret third state of mind: PRESSURE.

You have to start thinking about everything that will happen when you DON'T put in the work:

> I'll lose my clients
> I'll lose followers and leads
> I'll lose all of my progress so far
> I'll have to start from zero all over again...

Sometimes, you have to let your fears attack you and pressurise you.

Because when motivation and discipline fail, it's PRESSURE that keeps you afloat and going (and non-broke). Learn to leverage this pressure tactically.

What do you do when motivation and discipline fail?

#ShreyaWrites

"What's the logical thinking behind younger generations choosing a â‚¹15k-per-month freelancing role over a â‚¹50k-per-month full-time job?"

Udit Goenka asked this thought-provoking question in a tweet recently.

Here's my response:

Full-time yr 1: â‚¹50k per month
Full-time yr 2: â‚¹60k per month
Full-time yr 3: â‚¹70k per month

(^ Iâ€™m overestimating here)

Freelancing yr 1: â‚¹15k per month
Freelancing yr 2: â‚¹1 Lac per month
Freelancing yr 3: â‚¹1.5 Lac per month per client

(^ Iâ€™m underestimating here)

The logical and rational thinking here is the POTENTIAL.

Yes, you'll likely earn more initially in a job compared to as a freelancer. But your career and financial growth in a job are fixed...

Freelancing though? Limitless potential.Â 

Could be earning x one month and 3x the next.Â 
Could also drop down to 0.2x after that, and then go up to 10x.

Forget the money, there is also a thrill, a challenge in freelancing.

There's a constant battle between freedom and self-discipline;Â 
between getting comfortable and pushing your limits;Â 
between working for fixed hours a day and staying up all night for a passion project.

Not everyone can afford the thrill/ the challenge of course.

Yet there is something so exciting about the "Let's see what's the best I can do here" thought process.

It's not surprising that many end up freelancing along with their job.

Let's not forget this:

You get kicked out of a job? You're jobless for weeks. Months. You have no source of income.

A client lets you go as a freelancer? You already have 3 more. And you know exactly how to make money online by yourself. You'll get another source of income.

And of course, why are YOUNGER GENERATIONS preferring freelancing?

Because time and freedom >>> money.

When you have time, you can upskill
You can spend time with your family
You can create content online
You can build an audience
You can sleep well
You can be fit
You can live.

This is also in line with the concept of the "Time Billionaire.â€

Wouldn't you, at your age of 18-25, rather be the broke you that you are, than the 70-year-old billionaire?

Why? Because you are young.

You have energy
You have time
You are "alive" in ways that a 70yo billionaire isn't.

This is ALSO in line with the concept of "I didn't want to work a 9-5 so I became an entrepreneur and now I work 24x7â€¦â€

The number of hours of work doesn't matter when you're doing what YOU want to do, in YOUR own way.

In conclusion:

Preferring freelancing/ self-employment is a more logical decision by youngsters than preferring full-time employment. Regardless of the money and time involved.

It's obvious:
There is no better time to take risks than when you are young.

Take risks.

#ShreyaWrites

Every piece of writing advice I could come up with in 15 minutes, after writing for 10+ years: (Yes, I've been writing for over a DECADE)

1. Write like you talk, but edit like every single word will cost you $5

2. Stop researching as you write

3. Stop spellchecking as you write

4. Stop editing as you write

5. Sit down to write every day regardless of your mood

6. 30 minutes a day is all you need to improve your writing

7. Write the conclusion first so you know where you're headed

8. Write the introduction last, summarising everything

9. Prefer active voice over passive voice

10. Donâ€™t stress over the order. Write one line here, one line there - be random

11. Format it well and make your writing LOOK aesthetically appealing

12. When editing, ask yourself â€œSo what?â€ after every sentence. Canâ€™t answer the question? Edit/ delete the sentence

13. Kill your darlings

14. Donâ€™t report. Narrate

15. Skip the jargon - a 10yo should understand what you write

16. Donâ€™t write and edit on the same day

17. Delete adverbs

18. Write with ONE person in mind. Write "TO" them

19. Write every day

20. Write anything you want - journals, poems, essays, tweets, songs. Just write

21. Set writing goals - could be time (30 mins daily), milestone (1 chapter), or word count (500 words)

22. If you think too fast and write too slow, use an app like Otter to transcribe your audio to text; edit later

23. Use Hemingway Editor to check the readability quotient of your writing. Aim for Grade 3 - Grade 5

24. No amount of reading will help you improve your writing, unless you write more than you read

25. Emulate the writing style of your favourite writers to improve yours

26. Write early in the morning or late at night

27. Pick a platform and publish something every day

28. When learning how to write, quantity > quality

29. If your writing isnâ€™t improving, youâ€™re not writing enough

30. You don't need a critic to tell you you're getting better at writing; you'll feel it yourself

31. The easiest way to enjoy writing is to write something you WANT to write about. It could be something personal, write it down anyway

32. Donâ€™t expect instant results. Writing is not â€œjust wordsâ€

33. Donâ€™t pause to erase mistakes. Just strike them off and keep writing

This advice may look "simple", but read it again and ask yourself - how many of these do you follow?

Not enough, I bet.

So think of the advice being "simple" as a good thing - You can apply it instantly, and "effortlessly."

If you learned something, please like and share this post.

Follow me Shreya Pattar for more ðŸ˜Š

What if Virat Kohli did only cardio in the gym, and had no in-field cricket training? Would he be one of the best cricket players we've seen?

No, of course not.

Virat Kohli NEEDS in-field training.

That's how I feel about the idea of "doing an internship to gain experience as a freelancer..."

Yes, internships *might* help you learn the work itself, eg, social media management or article writing, etc. [Like I can be seen doing in the picture below...]

But those things make up only 5-10% of a successful freelancing career.Â 

Freelancing relies heavily (90-95%) on things that are not part of an internship:

â€¢ Lead generation
â€¢ Closing clients
â€¢ Personal branding
â€¢ Conducting sales calls
â€¢ Persuasion & proposals
â€¢ Setting terms & conditions
â€¢ Creating offers & setting prices
â€¢ Working with new people regularly
â€¢ Managing client concerns and issues...

You can't expect internships to teach you all these aspects of freelancing.

Freelancing is freelancing, and it requires hands-on experience in well... freelancing!

Now, you can still choose to take up an internship to learn how to do a particular task.Â 

However, consider whether you want to take up the 40+ hours a week of stress and extra time involvement (eg. travel) that comes with an internship, or instead use that time to learn to freelance as soon as possible.

Bottom line:

If you want to be a freelancer, start freelancing.
Â

â€œYou could have saved a lot of money by living at home but you moved to Dubai and you call it an investment. In what way exactly is moving to Dubai an investment for you?â€

Many people have asked me this question since I moved to Dubai this February.

From the monetary perspectiveâ€¦ Hereâ€™s how I have found my environment to influence financial growth:

When I started freelancing, I was studying in Dublin, Ireland (Thatâ€™s my university in the picture.)

At the time, making â‚¬500 a month as a beginner was a huge thing. I thought â€œWow this is probably higher than what a job would pay meâ€¦â€

So I was very happy with what I was earning.

But then I realised, â‚¬500 is nothing in Dublin. My monthly rent itself was double of that. Plus I had living expenses. Plus I had college fees.

My parents were sponsoring my education, but I wanted to contribute towards easing this out.

So I HAD to earn more.

ðŸŽ¯ My first goal was to pay my daily expenses myself. The initial â‚¬500 covered that.

ðŸŽ¯ Then I made a goal to pay my rent.
+ â‚¬1000 a month. I did it.

ðŸŽ¯ Then I made a goal to pay my tuition.
+â‚¬22,000 a year. I did it.

The point is: If I didnâ€™t have all those motivations (ahem ahem, expenses) to push me towards earning more, I would have never tested my limits.

ðŸ«¶ðŸ» Thatâ€™s what I mean by moving to another city/ country - that time Dublin, this time Dubai - being an â€œinvestment.â€

The benefits and results come in various forms and ways, and this was mine when I was in Ireland.

I cannot pinpoint how my new environment will help me, but this is how my environment pushed me in the past.

â€¼ï¸ This post isnâ€™t about moving abroad; or even about moving at all. Itâ€™s about getting out of your comfort zone, finding encouragement in certain challenges, and doing your best for yourself.

I hope this helps :)

Do you want your stories to go viral but fear the toxicity that may come with it?

LinkedIn is an excellent platform for content creation that is known for its high organic reach.

But this high organic reach often comes with gaining massive engagement on posts, which also means a fair share of trolls/ nasty comments...

If you are new to creating content on LinkedIn and find the possible toxicity nerve-wracking, here are some ways to overcome that fear:

#1. Follow the proven, "cliche" writing style without fear of judgment. Your story is YOUR story; you don't need to try and reinvent the wheel with how you say it.

#2. Be honest in your writing and realise that you donâ€™t owe anyone any justification.

#3. Anticipate follow-up questions, and be prepared for these comments BEFORE you hit â€˜publish.â€™

#4. Avoid words that may dilute your key message, or take the reader off on a tangent.Â Edit ruthlessly.

#5. The trolls will exist, but they will also remain in tiny numbers when your success is big. Focus on the big picture; on the good stuff.

#6. Ignore, block or mute the trolls and the argumentative/ toxic comments, and engage only with the ones that will add value to your post.Â 

#7. If you are new to LinkedIn and get high engagement on your posts, avoid reading the comments (until you know can learn to ignoreÂ negative comments.)

#8. Move on to writing your next post. Your audience is waiting!

Do you still fear hitting â€œPublishâ€ on LinkedIn?

"Shreya, how do you maintain work-life balance?"

Well... I don't.

In fact, I think work-life balance is a myth. And chasing work-life balance is a run towards nothing.

I mean, think about it: Do we ever talk about "Love - Life" balance?

"Health - Life" balance?

"Family - Life" balance?

"Happiness - Life" balance?

"Relationship - Life" balance?

"Mental health - Life" balance?

No.

Why not?

Well, I can think of 3 reasons:

#1. Because these are not terms that are fed to us regularly by media, unlike the term "work-life balance."

#2. Because we understand that each of these things has its ups and downs.

â€‹We don't try to "balance" things out when it comes to health, relationships, family or happiness. We understand that these elements are not in our control, and we will ride a new wave every day with them.
â€‹
It is only in the ups and downs of work that we freak out the most.

We think that if something is NOT going right work-wise, then we have made some intentional mistake that now needs to be brought back to balance.

We think that if something IS going well work-wise, then we should pause and slow down and focus on the other things in life too to create the right balance. Both these approaches then hinder our growth for unworthy reasons.

#3. Because these terms just sound absurd.

â€‹Love - Life balance, Health - Life balance... umm, what? That's absurd.

â€‹After all, what even is life without health - physical & mental, family, and relationships? We simply cannot segregate these things from "life." Otherwise, how do we even define life?

The same holds true for work. Work is not life in itself, yet work is a large chunk of it. There is more to life than work, yet work is a huge part of life. And life cannot be defined without work.


So yes, I don't aim for "work-life balance."

I only aim to live a fulfilling life, where I am able to create time to work on what I love and enjoy, every day :)

What's your idea of "work-life balanceâ€?

#ShreyaWrites

The fear of self-investment:

For newbies, when it comes to financial (especially stock market & crypto) investment, one of our main concern is the uncertainty of rate of returns.

Itâ€™s the uncertainty of when returns may come, and the uncertainty of protection of principal.

(We have no guarantee that we wonâ€™t even lose the amount of money we have invested, let alone guarantee a positive RoI.)

I think the same happens for investing in oneself too.

We may fear investing in ourselves wholeheartedly - could be education, business, health, recreational activities - because we donâ€™t know what returns our investment will bring and when they will bring us the returns.

However, there is one stark difference between both kinds of investments - Control.

In the first kind of investment, you are at the mercy of factors beyond your control (no control over the stock market or crypto market).

In self-investment though, you have full control over the actions you take, and hence have a modicum of control over the results you generate. Also, your learnings can transmute and bring a positive RoI in other areas of your life.

This is why I think that people who stop investing in themselves do it because they feel they are not in control, and so they don't trust themselves to invest in themselves.

They donâ€™t trust themselves to take the responsibility to improve upon themselves; to keep themselves accountable; to take the action they know they need to take.

And because of this, they fear the failure that they know they are guaranteeing for themselves.

Donâ€™t be this person.

Invest in yourself.

And work towards getting the RoI you aim to accrue.

#ShreyaWrites

9 simple writing tips that you can apply in the next 5 minutes to improve your writing forever:

[#8 is the tip you never knew you needed]

1. Turn off spellcheck while youâ€™re writing - you wonâ€™t get distracted by the red underlines.

2. Keep 1 person in mind while writing anything, and write only for them.

3. Make writing a part of your daily routine - it could be a goal to write x words every day, or to write for x minutes every day - up to you.

4. If you think faster than you write and that affects the quality, then use an app like Otter to transcribe your audio to text; edit later.

5. You donâ€™t need to start writing from the beginning (in fact, you shouldn't) - write in any random order that suits you and piece things together later.

6. Write your conclusion first, so you have clarity on what point you need to make through the rest of the piece and you can reverse-engineer it.

7. Write your introduction last, so you can accurately summarise the rest of the piece while creating a build-up to read it all.

8. Write like you talk, but edit like every single word is going to cost you $5.

9. Use Hemingway Editor to check the readability quotient of your writing, and aim to achieve a level of Grade 3 - Grade 5.

#ShreyaWrites

14 things I wish I knew before I started freelancing:

[3, 10, and 14 are my favourites]

1. Stop trying to look only at revenue as a freelancer. Freelance to add value; revenue will follow.

2. If you want to make more sales, study concepts from both, psychology and marketing.

3. Donâ€™t be afraid of scaling too fast. You donâ€™t need to struggle and toil for years to hit $10K months. You can do it in under a year.

4. Regular content creation will get you 3-5 leads a day, in under a year. Want to get leads in your sleep? Create content.

5. Donâ€™t rely only on content creation for lead generation. Use other methods too, especially some form of outbound.

6. You donâ€™t need a degree, or rather any work experience at all. Just get your skills to a level where it can be of value to other people.

7. Listen more than you talk. Act more than you think. Create more than you doubt.

8. Freelancing is a numbers game. The more content you create/ outreach you do/ calls you book, the better outcome you will get.

9. A sustainable freelancing income is better created through client retention than lead generation. Aim to retain as many clients as possible each month.

10. Prioritise your health. You rely 100% on yourself as a freelancer, and this career choice demands that you be your fittest self to succeed in it.

11. Freelancing is meant to be treated as a business, not a quick rich scheme. Give it time, energy and effort for the long term.

12. If you are underbooked, you need to focus on lead gen and sales. If you are overbooked, you need to raise your prices.
Â 
13. Your focus should not be to hit $100K as soon as possible just because everyoneâ€™s doing it. It should be to set and chase goals that are meaningful to you.

It's my birthday! Sharing 10 of my thoughts/ reflections/ learnings from the last year, in no particular order (You can read all 21 in my newsletter):

1. Contrary to popular opinion, authenticity is not everything. You need to be intentional in life. Without intention, you will drift, become stagnant and keep hanging by the thread of "But but I need to stay true to myself..." Be intentional with everything you think or do.

2. Health comes first. Health is one of the few things that money cannot buy. (Yes, money could pay your hospital bills, but even for that to work, your body needs to be strong enough to fight for itself.) Eat right, breathe right, move, sleep well & prioritise your health.

3. You should trust yourself the most in this entire world. You should be the first person you can think of who will never disappoint you. And the only way to do that is to stick to the promises you make to yourself, give it your best, and not let yourself down.

4. "Vibe" is a real metric to consider when you meet new people or face new situations. The energy people radiate and how their energy radiates with you - it's not something to be ignored. Your understanding of vibes may not be accurate yet, but it will become more so with time.

5. "How was your day" is a good question to ask others. "What did you do today?" is a better question to ask yourself. As time goes by, aim to increase the quality of the list of things you did in a day.

6. There is nothing to "figure out." You figure something out and you realise itâ€™s not what you wanted to figure out. Or you figure something out & realise itâ€™s all still messy anyway. Just do what you've got to do, and you will learn, mould, and see results over time.

7.Â Letting go of anything at all, people, situations, mistakes, experiencesâ€¦ is in your control. It is a conscious decision you must make and act towards. Rather than trying to hate these experiences, become indifferent to them. That's where the real mental freedom lies.
Â 
8.Â Call your parents, siblings, family, and friends often, even if only for a few minutes. You need them in your life - To help you overcome the bad, and also to be there to celebrate the good with you. They need you in their life too. Be there for each other.Â 

9.Â EVERYTHING is your fault. Take responsibility for every single thing in your life. If you mess up, it's your fault. If you don't do it, it's your fault. If you do it but don't get results, it's your fault. The best? If you succeed in it, it's still your fault.Â 

10.Â Contrary to what social media makes you believe, there is so much good in the world. There is beauty, happiness, love, purity, honesty, loyalty & trust. There is something worth fighting for. You need to believe in them, only then will you be lucky enough to experience them.

Thank you all so much for your lovely wishes, and for caring about what I write, create, and share every day with you. Thank you â¤ï¸

#ShreyaWrites

"I have a Master's degree in XYZ but I learnt more from these 7 YouTube videos..."

^ I've been seeing a lot of people talk about this lately.

Here's how I see it:

If you find YouTube videos and threads to be of super-duper high value, then a lot of credit goes to your degree too.

It's simple: You were able to grasp and leverage the high level of information in the YouTube videos because of the work you've put in towards your degree.

Your foundations are strong;
You understand the ins and outs of what you've studied
(even if you didn't pay much attention in class),
And you can comprehend vague information in ways that the average person - without a Master's degree in that field - can't.

Your Master's degree holds its own importance in how you are able to make the most of the information you have access to online.

So does that mean you NEED a Master's degree to know something in-depth? No.

Does it mean you NEED a Master's degree to "make it"? No.

But remember that one video/ thread/ podcast/ book isn't going to cut it either.

YOU need to take up the responsibility of self-learning and immerse yourself in the topic. You need to be accountable for your own intellectual growth; and you need to put in effort consistently, and over the long term.

So, what are you learning right now?

Last week, 4,878 readers in my newsletter learnt my LinkedIn content strategy. Here's a snapshot:

#1. The Plan

I've planned out my target audience, frequency, the theme of posts and the purpose of each theme. I jot down each idea keeping these in mind.

#2. The Tools

I use Airtable for drafting and saving all my content for future reference. In the newsletter, I also shared my Content Calendar Template for you to reuse. I don't use any scheduling tools for LinkedIn.

#3. The Content

I spend 1 hour a month coming up with 30-60 LinkedIn post ideas, and then spend 10-15 minutes everyday writing a post. (The newsletter includes examples of how I repurpose my tweets for LinkedIn.)

#4. The Process

I list the post ideas, and then pick one idea every day to create a post. I publish the post manually on LinkedIn and update the link on Airtable. Finally, I add a CTA in the comment box of the post as well (Link to my ebooks/ newsletter/ coaching call etc.)

This is only an overview of my newsletter. If you want to get the entire newsletter - including my templates and examples - click the link in the comments.

I hope this helps!

"Engaging 20x a day" to grow your LinkedIn brand is hard. That's because 99% of posts on our feeds are not engagement-worthy at all.

Here are 5 ways to find engagement-worthy posts on your feed:

1. Click on specific hashtags that are relevant to your interests/ target audience - eg. #linkedinbranding - and engage with posts under those hashtags. This way you'll skip all the spammy posts on your feed and only find topics you want to read.

2. Make a list of the people that publish engagement-worthy content regularly. Save their profile URLs in your phone/ desktop's Notes app. Then click these links every day and engage with the latest post of your favourite creators.

3. Instead of engaging on posts for 30 minutes straight, engage for 5-10 minutes at a time, multiple times throughout the day. This way you get a better mix of content to engage with.

4. Scroll through and find as many valuable posts as you can. Then refresh the page when the good posts are exhausted.

5. Engage only with high-quality content. The better quality posts you engage with, the more the feed will show similar posts. (The customers of my ebook Ca$hing In on LinkedIn have tried this out and seen good results within a week.)

"Agree?" is not a CTA. It's an engagement repellant.

Instead of using the "A" word,
Invite your audience to:

1. Comment meaningfully on your post

Ask a thoughtful question that would enhance the value/ point of your post. Comments by the first few people will also inspire more readers to share their views and experiences on your post.

2. Message you

There are many ways to do this - The most common is to highlight a pain point of your audience and encourage them to DM you for information/ advice.

3. Check your profile and follow you

Perhaps you've updated your bio. Or you've added new links to your Featured Section. Or you've received new recommendations. Let your audience know and ask them for their feedback by inviting them to check your profile. (Or simply ask them to follow you.)

4. Sign up for your offer

Be it a free newsletter, an ebook, a product, a service, or a consultation call - you can promote something, free or paid, in your post. Make sure you add the links in the comment box and not in the post itself.

Do this, and take your CTA from engagement repellant to leads and money magnet.

"Agree?"

How to apply the AIDA Marketing Model to your LinkedIn Posts:

Attention = Strong Hook

The hook of the post grabs attention and makes your audience want to read the rest of the post and follow you. To develop a strong hook, first, write down multiple options. Then pick one that you like most.Â 

Interest = Build-Up

In writing, a build-up creates excitement and intrigue before the main punchline comes through.Â In a LinkedIn post, the first 2 to 3 lines that follow the hook create the build-up. Use this space to add context to your hook.Â 

Desire = More Build-up

Now that you've held your audience's attention, it's time to give them a "drumroll" feeling that makes them want to keep reading and find out the conclusion of the post. Donâ€™t try to introduce a new idea at this point, only expand on what you're written so far.

Action = The "Big Bang" + CTA

This is the point where the drumroll in the readerâ€™s head pauses, and they get the â€œbig revealâ€ theyâ€™ve all been waiting for: the takeaway from your post. Ensure that this lives up to the expectations you've created through your build-up â€” Only then will your audience want to engage with your post.

Will you try this strategy?

#ShreyaWrites

"If I post more than 1x a week, my audience will get annoyed and my profile won't grow"

I have heard this time and time again from prospects on my discovery calls. Here's why this notion is false and limiting:

1. Limited audience reach:

With every post, you will only reach a small % of your audience. And with every post, this audience will largely be different. So, no, a higher frequency of posts won't annoy your audience - because most of them won't see your content regularly in the first place.

2. Limited opportunities:

Posting 1x a week will slow down your growth. When you post only 1x a week (or 4x a month), you have the opportunity that only 4 posts bring for increasing your reach, generating leads, and building an audience.

On the other hand, if you post a minimum of 3x a week, you'll drive in opportunities through 12 posts a month - each seen by a different segment of your audience.

3. Limited brand recall:

Much of your audience is a silent watcher. They may not engage with your posts; they may not even connect with you or follow you - But they'll know you and your work through your consistency. They may see your posts through people in their network who engage with you, or they may regularly check back on your profile to read your posts.

So when you consistently create content in a specific niche, you build brand recall, and, subconsciously, become the go-to expert in that niche for your audience.

^ Try this out for only 30 days, and you'll see the difference.

And if a higher content frequency overwhelms you, let me help you out. DM me "consult" to book a paid LinkedIn Strategy Call with me.

For some, $1000 a month is a high-ticket offer,
For some, $10,000 a month,
And for some, even $100,000 a month is not high-ticket.

Clearly, there is no fixed number that makes your offering "high ticket."

ðŸ’° So hereâ€™s how I define a high-ticket offer: A high-ticket offer is one that, in itself, is worth the sum of all your clientâ€™s invoices.

For example, say you have 3 clients:

Client 1 - Pays you $200 a month
Client 2 - Pays you $150 a month
Client 3 - Pays you $150 a month.

This brings your total income to $500 every month.

ðŸ’° Now, a high-ticket offer for you would be one that is worth $400-$500 in itself.

So if you close Client 4 for $500 a month, that is your high-ticket offer (and high-ticket client.)

ðŸ’° As you grow, the definition and value of your high-ticket offer will keep changing over months and years.

Say you consistently have 4 clients paying you a total of $1000 a month, then your next high-ticket offer will be worth $800-1000 per month.

Hope this helps!

What do you think of this? How do you define high-ticket offers?

1. The higher the value of your offer, the more your revenue per client and the fewer clients you need to work with.

2. The intensity and need for lead generation will depend on your offer. With a high-ticket offer, you need only 4-5 clients per month to hit six figures.

3. â€œMarket saturationâ€ is irrelevant to you as a freelancer. You donâ€™t need 1000 clients to run a six-figure business.

4. Excellent service means the same clients will likely renew on a monthly/ quarterly basis.

ðŸ¤ With this perspective:

1. Create your high-ticket offer

2. Reach out to prospects daily and aim to close your first 3 clients ASAP

3. Focus on the execution of your services to increase client retention.

ðŸ˜‡ Itâ€™s not going to be easy, but it is possible!

â—ï¸ Contrary to popular opinion, freelancing is NOT a â€œwork for 3 hours a day and make $10K a monthâ€ kind of career.

Here are some not-so-well-known â€œbaggageâ€ (or, less dramatically, challenges) of freelancing:

â° Work Hours

You are likely to start with working 8-12+ hours a day; 7 days a week; at odd hours; and by yourself.

Like most things though, this too gets easier with time. And you will be able to free up more time for various other interests

ðŸ’¥ Uncertainty/ Instability

Your first year, or even a couple of years, will come with lots of uncertainty and instability.

You will have good months and bad months and some best months - and this will make your income stable on an annual basis. But month by month uncertainty will be present initially.

ðŸ¥Š Constant Hustle

As you grow, your services and client work itself will become a small part of it all.

Soon you would want to expand and explore more opportunities,
Turn into an agency,
Create more content,
Increase production quality and consistency etc.

âŒ›ï¸ Mental Overload

And all of that Constant Hustle can easily to lead to a mental overload. It might become difficult to separate your work and work-oriented goals from simple day-to-day activities, and you may end up thinking about work and clients and growth 24x7.

Iâ€™ve been there, and itâ€™s a REAL struggle looking past this.

ðŸ§  Mindset Shifts

Made your first $? You need a big mindset shift to make your first $500, and then again for $1000.

Closed your first client? You need a big mindset shift to close your next 5, and then again for 10.

Hired your first teammate? You need a big mindset shift to hire your next 5, then again for your next 10.

The mindset shifts and growth are a continuous process and you need to keep pushing for it beyond your comfort zone.

~ On focus: The kind no one talks about ~

I follow a lot of fitness accounts on Instagram:

@aja_cortesÂ talks about muscle + strength building - especially through his programs that target specific muscle groups.

@syattfitnessÂ talks about heart rate training zones and heart healthâ€¦ and also about counting calories weekly not daily. Recently he also said that his wife tracks only protein + fibre, not calories.

@kneesovertoesguyÂ talks about knee health and the unusual exercises in his ATG routine

@coachmarkcarrollÂ talks about the common mistakes and the tiniest things to focus on in each workout

@bretcontreras1Â talks about efficient glute exercises - often different from others who show the same workout.

Everyone is correct yet different in their approach to fitness.

ðŸ§  Subconsciously, I thought each of these things should become my goal now:

â€œI need to learn whatâ€™s Zone 2 and track my heart rateâ€

â€œI was already struggling with protein and calories, I need to track fibre too now??â€

â€œIf I want good knees I need to add this program?â€

My brain started setting up too many related yet unrelated goals.

Then I decided:

ðŸš« NOPE.

Iâ€™m going to follow ONE program and ONLY one program.

Iâ€™ll continue to learn about the mechanics and science of workouts and nutrition from all these coachesâ€¦

But when it comes to whose advice to follow NOW, I am picking ONE person and following them to the T - for workout plans, cardio options, diet recommendations, tracking methods - everything.

Now I am much more aligned with what I am doing + where I see myself headed.

ðŸ¤” Why am I sharing this with you?

Because the same applies to freelancing advice/ freelancing coaches too.

Taking advice from too many people will confuse, overwhelm and mentally tire you.

If you like someoneâ€™s strategies/ advice, follow only their advice for 6-12 months. Do everything they say, exactly as they say it.

Because itâ€™s not just ONE thing they say that will make a difference for youâ€¦ rather it is the SUM of EVERYTHING they advise that works in harmony to bring you the best results.

ðŸ¤ Pick ONE person and follow them to the T.

#ShreyaWrites

I was telling my dad last week how different life is now in early 20s than it might have been for him, "Income is low; expenses are higher than ever, and even fundamentals like houses & cars are unaffordable. You canâ€™t really â€˜settleâ€™ young these days. There's just too much stress now."

My dad said, â€œStress existed back then too, but at the time you just shut up & dealt with it.â€

And that got me thinking:

If I didn't see the words â€˜stressâ€™ or â€˜pressureâ€™ in others' posts/ captions/ memes 10x a day, would I be using them to describe my daily life?

Would I be so aware of the â€˜stressâ€™ - a natural force required to grow - that everything is exerting on me?

I wouldn't.

But now because I am bombarded with the concept of stress & am hyper-aware of the stresses (which, again, are natural & necessary), â€˜stressâ€™ is my go-to word to describe everything, all day.

â€œFreelancing is stressfulâ€¦â€

â€œCreating content is stressfulâ€¦â€

â€œThis work is causing me so much stressâ€¦â€

In that way, all aspects of freelancing are â€˜stressful.â€™

Butâ€¦ What isnâ€™t?

Just because everything adds its own stress doesnâ€™t mean we go about acknowledging it every single time, or go about looking for ways to get rid of the stress â€” quitting being one of the most common ways.

This thought process leads to more stress about seeking & waiting for an idealistic â€˜normal, 100% happy, all-good-things lifeâ€™ that does not exist.

I've thought a lot about this lately and I've come to this conclusion:

Skip the "I'm stressed", "This is so stressful" self/ public talk. Consciously pull yourself away from it.

Tell yourself "Shut up and deal with it" more often.

And once you've dealt with that stress, a new one will be waiting for you... Repeat.

#ShreyaWrites

P.S. This post is not for you if you have any medical issues or such related to stress.

21 lessons I learnt in 2021:

[Derived from some of my most thoughtful/ heartfelt/ vulnerable/ mindful writings from different times throughout the year]

1. Things will take their own time, and youâ€™ve got to let them. While you â€œwaitâ€ for things to work out, donâ€™t put your life on a halt. Create; learn; practise; rest; get strongerâ€¦ Make the most of the waiting period.

2. You can improve 100x within a minute if you set your mind towards something. You can hit every note in your vocals class; you can lift your heaviest barbell; you can play your best game. Be in charge of your mind & youâ€™ll almost conquer the action (if not the result)

3. Donâ€™t just try to avoid losses in life; focus more on winning new things. Trying to avoid losses will make you desperate for the win. That desperation will lead to desperate actions, which will often lead you to lose that thing anyway.

4. A lot of things are not in your control. It is what it is. Let it be.

5. More things are in your control than you think. It is what you make it. Work on it and make it happen for you.

6. Your intuition is always right. If something feels â€œoffâ€, it highly likely is. Pause, reflect and then act â€” you might just have the power to make it right.

7. Family comes first. They are your ride-and-die. They are your biggest cheerleaders. Always stick close to them.

8. When you find the momentum to do something, donâ€™t let it go. Leverage it, build it, capitalise on it. Momentum is often short-lived, make the most of it.

9. Move. Eat right. Lift heavy. Then lift heavier. Your skin, hair, nails, heart, mind and soul will thank you for it.

10. Stop being over-excited about your achievements. You deserve those achievements for your hard work â€” you should see them coming. Be level-headed.

11. Create something every day. Creating is the most personally rewarding and freeing thing to do.

12. Learn something because you love it. Look for reasons other than monetisation to spend hours on something.

13. Spend time with yourself; spend some money on yourself. Buy a course, a fancy dinner, a new dress, a new membershipâ€¦ Celebrate yourself.

14. Something affecting you personally does not imply youâ€™re weak or need â€œfixing.â€ Sometimes it only means that the situations and circumstances are crappyâ€¦ and youâ€™re human.

15. At times you will be the smartest, most successful person you know. At other times, you will be the most stupid and naive person you know. Embrace both sides of yourself, and keep turning the stupid-naive times into more of the smart-successful times.

#ShreyaWrites

What if Virat Kohli did only cardio in the gym, and had no in-field cricket training? Would he be one of the best cricket players we've seen?

No, of course not.

Virat Kohli NEEDS in-field training.

That's how I feel about internships & freelancing too: Internships will not teach you how to freelance.

Yes, internships *might* help you learn the work itself, eg, social media management or article writing etc.

But those things make up only 5-10% of a successful freelancing career.

Freelancing relies heavily (90-95%) on things that are not part of an internship:

â€¢ Lead generation (most important!)
â€¢ Personal branding
â€¢ Creating services & setting prices
â€¢ Persuasion & proposals
â€¢ Conducting sales calls
â€¢ Closing clients
â€¢ Dealing with payments
â€¢ Setting terms & conditions
â€¢ Managing client concerns and issues
â€¢ Working with new people regularly.

You can't expect internships to teach you all these aspects of freelancing.

Freelancing is freelancing, and it requires hands-on experience in well... freelancing!

Now, you can still choose to take up an internship to learn how to do a particular task.

However, consider whether you want to take up the 40+ hours a week of stress and extra time-involvement (eg. travel) that comes with an internship,

Or instead use that time to learn freelancing as soon as possible.

Bottom line:

If you want to be a freelancer, start freelancing.

Top 7 takeaways from my Twitter Spaces co-hosted with @lifemathmoney:

#ONE. The difference between LinkedIn & Twitter?

Twitter can be more overwhelming than LinkedIn. You can get by on LinkedIn with 1 post every alternate day; but Twitter demands 3-5 tweets per day + tons of engagement.

LinkedIn also won't let you be anonymous :)

#TWO. Once youâ€™re successful, most people will say you just got lucky.

They wonâ€™t realise that luck is self-generated: You create luck for yourself through your own actions and hard work.

#THREE. Have Writersâ€™ Block?

@lifemathmoney goes for a walk - without a phone or headphones. Once heâ€™s back, heâ€™s able to start writing easily.

@shreyapattar (me) just stares at a blank document for 10-30 mins. It allows my brain to reorganise my thoughts, and then start writing.

#FOUR. Tons of people make tons of money online only by... selling courses on how to make money online!

They sell well probably 'coz most of these courses are plagiarised - just because they are cheap/ by non-experts doesnâ€™t mean they donâ€™t have value.

#FIVE. You are one DM away from finding your first client and making money online.

#SIX. Freelancing is 10% dependent on your core skill, and 90% about prospecting, sales, negotiation, people skills, etc.

If you want to start freelancing, don't try to "perfect" your skill; focus on finding your first client ASAP.

#SEVEN. The content creation space is crowded now thanks to the pandemic. Once people get back to their busy, â€œnormal livesâ€, this number will go down drastically.

If you want to stand out, create quality content and stick to it long-term.

I freelanced while studying full-time for 3 years. Then I graduated early because I was able to scale my biz pretty wellâ€¦ while attending lectures, events & more.

Here are 8 simple tips for managing freelance work as a student, based on personal experience:

#ONE Realise freelancing while studying full-time is going to be challenging.

Youâ€™ll have to sacrifice some sleep, outings & gatherings. Mentally prepare yourself for that challenge.

#TWO Pay full attention to college lectures; donâ€™t try to sneak work in at that time.

Maximise your lecture time for learning, rather than struggling in the last-minute.

#THREE Complete your college assignments asap.

Iâ€™m more of a research-and-create-an-outline-immediately-but-wait-until-the-last -5-hours-to-write-the-essay kind of personâ€¦ but thatâ€™s overwhelming. Just finish your assignments asap so you are mentally free & focused.

#FOUR Use the time between lectures.

If you have long breaks, use it for sales calls or doing client work. If you have short breaks, respond to DMs and emails, and set up calls. Also write a post or two for your social media.

#FIVE Make the most of your weekends.

I spent about 15 hrs every weekend working for my clients, compared to 2-3 hours per day during the week.

#SIX Increase your rates & decrease the number of clients.

Youâ€™ll keep making the same monthly revenue (or more), while also working with fewer clients. Experiment with this for every new sales calls you get on.

#SEVEN Start outsourcing.

Hire one person. Give them some work, see how they do, see how you feel about it. Then hire one more. Then one more. Remember: Anyone you hire should reduce your time involvement, not increase it or complicate it.

#EIGHT Plan & prepare in advance.

Inform clients asap if you need more time for a task. Donâ€™t take on new clients during exam week. Continue taking sales calls even when youâ€™re fully booked. Book clients a few weeks or months in advance, perhaps with a refundable deposit.

Comment any questions you have about freelancing as a student!

I HATED walking my puppy. He always pulled me along on his leash and NEVER walked straightâ€¦ until today.

Hereâ€™s what happened [& 3 life-changing lessons you can learn from this]:

I have a Doberman puppy, Harvey (aka best boi.) Heâ€™s 7 months old; weighs over 80lbs.

In the 3 months that I have been home, I have only â€œwalkedâ€ him ONCE. Now only my dad does.ï¿¼

Why? Because Harvey is a huge puppyâ€¦ and the distractions in India are too many to have a peaceful walk without looking around all the time. So now he easily pulls us along with him on the leash.

This turned the walks into a mentally & physically stressful workout.

Yes, we had a dog trainer, but their leash-walking methods were not working well.

So today we had a new dog trainer come over â€” Someone who specialises in training big dogs, and someone who has trained multiple Dobermans before.

This changed everythingâ€¦

As soon as this new dog trainer came in, he showed us a â€˜slip lead with a nose loop.â€™ (Example in picture 2)

The main function of this slip lead and nose loop is to control the HEAD of the dog.

The leash itself is very comfortable for the dog and does not bother them, but a slight tug on the leash will instantly turn the dogâ€™s head in your direction.

So every time Harvey was distracted by something,
The trainer tugged the leash,
Harveyâ€™s head turned towards the trainer,
He lost eye contact with that distraction,
And he continued to walk straight ahead.

(Of course the good boi got many treats during the training!)

And thatâ€™s how the leash-pulling problem was solved in just one minute: By using a slip lead to regularly turn Harveyâ€™s head away from the distractions.

Because, as the dog trainer said, â€œYou control the head, you control the dog.â€

This 15-minute experience taught me 3 MAJOR lessons:

#ONE. When hiring anyone, hire experts for your specific need.

Our previous trainer had trained many dogs before, but never a Doberman. This ineffective training in puppyhood led to bigger problems over the monthsâ€¦ which could have been avoided by hiring a Doberman expert.

#TWO. Donâ€™t overlook issues when they are small.

Harvey has been pulling on his leash for quite some time now. We thought it was puppy excitement and will fade over time â€” not true. Had we focused on this problem sooner, it wouldnâ€™t have gotten to such a stressful point.

#THREE. Your head controls your body.

The world is full of distractions. Your head will always have something to look at & focus on, BUT not everything is worth that focus.

YOU must be your own slip lead & pull your head away from distractions.

Control your head; control your body.

#ShreyaWrites

After 3 months of work?

When youâ€™re okay with losing the client.

How can freelancers handle multiple clients?

Usually the response would be:
Either â€˜make time for the workâ€™,
or â€˜decline new projects if you cannot make time for them.â€™

Hereâ€™s something more from my freelancing experience:

#ONE. Realise that you donâ€™t need to work for every single client every single day.

For example, I give 2-3 hours a week to each of my client (say, 5-7 hours a week if I didnâ€™t have a team.) Instead of doing this as 1-2 hours of work every single day, I have fixed days for each client â€” say, client 1 on Tuesdays.

Not only does this help me get the work done fast, but it also helps my brain work more creatively by focusing on the same client at a stretch.

This is especially useful for projects that go on for a few weeks or months, unlike a one-off article.

#TWO. Donâ€™t take up one-off work, unless it is incredibly high-paying.

If you donâ€™t have a choice and NEED to accept such work, by all means, go ahead and do it.

But be aware that the more smaller projects you undertake, the more work you have to do. ALSO! The more smaller projects you take up, the more clients you have to deal with. So youâ€™re not â€œspending 2 hours writing an articleâ€, but spending much more time adjusting to a new client, raising a new invoice, waiting for a new payment, making new kinds of edits, etc.

Which means...

#THREE. Prioritise monthly projects.

â€œBut Shreya, no one hires me for a full month...â€

Thatâ€™s not the main problem.

The main problem is you not having an offer worth a recurring monthly retainer.

You then miss out on converting a one-off prospect into a monthly retainer client.

So set up a monthly, preferably high-ticket offer first. Then LIST people who can benefit from the offer, and REACH OUT to them on various platforms or via email. Donâ€™t keep waiting for them to approach you.

9-Step Checklist For Sharing Your Articles With Your Clients â¬‡ï¸

1. Center align the headline. Justify align the body.

2. Use H2 or H3 for the headline. Use "Normal Text" for the body.

3. Use Title Case for headline.

4. Provide 1-2 alternatives for the headlines. The topics provided by clients are usually explanatory, and need to be turned into crisp, impactful headlines.

5. Make the subheadings bold so they stand out.

6. Hit "enter" after every bullet point. Spacing out points/ paragraphs makes the article visually appealing.

7. Always cross-check the accuracy of the content. Eg, the heading says "7 key points", but the article has only 5.

8. If your heading mentions "7 key points", the points should be mentioned in number 1-7, not with bullets.

9. Add page break after each article.

How many of these do you follow?

Comment any questions.

â€œI just canâ€™t do itâ€
â€œItâ€™s not meant for meâ€

I hear & see such words repeatedly in my 1:1 consultation calls & my DMs.

This is self-deprecating talk, which usually starts out as a way to appear modest.

Letâ€™s say you made a painting.

Your friend says, â€œWhat a beautiful painting!â€

You respond, â€œNot at all. Look at this line & this colour... itâ€™s all off.â€

This â€˜modestyâ€™ very easily turns into a defensive belief system.

Now every time you paint, you think â€œThis line & this colour are wrong...â€

This leads to:

1. Deep dissatisfaction with any of your paintings
2. Possibly giving up on painting completely.

Soon this self-deprecative talk spreads to all other areas of your life.

Eventually, something that started as â€˜modestyâ€™ becomes an excuse that keeps you stagnant.

And it pulls you down. Really low.

The solution?

Celebrate your victories & achievements, however â€˜smallâ€™ & â€˜insignificantâ€™ they appear to you.

And start seeing failure as a failure (an opportunity to improve upon or move on); not something to glorify or wallow in.

Stop using self-deprecative talk.

Value yourself.
Only then will the world value you.

When you apply to a foreign university, they arenâ€™t just looking for a â€œgood studentâ€. They are looking for what YOU can offer them, and how you will amplify their brand/ institutional name.

Your academic marks are just the minimum entry requirement for a foreign university.

And the number of students who meet the minimum marks criteria is huge. This means thousands of applicants have similar grades, thousands have done similarly well in their academics, and thousands have met the minimum requirements in their SATs or IELTS or TOEFL.

So, how does the university decides who should join them?

Thatâ€™s where everything apart from your grades gets factored in:

Your values
Your work ethic
Your skills
Your passions
Your interests
Your internships
Your achievements
Your motivation to study
Your plans for college
Your goals after completing college
What you intend to do with what has been taught to you...

These things are a part of your SOP, so make sure you invest time in writing, rewriting, and yet again rewriting it.

These decide your acceptance.

Make the university believe in your potential because of your past accomplishments. Good luck!

8 years ago, a startup raised a seed fund of US $1.3 million. They never raised any further capital, and are now valued at $4 billion.

This sort of low funding towards a billion-dollar valuation is rather unusual for any startup.

But Zapier, an online automation tool that connects your apps and services, made it happen.

How?

By raising a seed fund, and then chasing customers, not VCs.

This had allowed the founders to own 80% shares! This is incredibly rare for any successful startup.

Most startups, upon raising a seed fund, continue to look for VCs who can fund them further. And keep diluting their equity.

But, by focusing on customer acquisition, instead of growth for growth sake, Zapier generated its own revenue and became profitable.

What adds to their profitability is that team has been working remotely right from the beginning.

Today, Zapier has 350 employees. And all of them continue to work remotely.

So, what's the takeaway?

1. Raise a seed fund and be profitable as soon as possible
2. Chase customers, not VCs
3. Use your resources to add value and gain paying customers.

What's your favourite takeaway?

#ShreyaWrites

P.S. Lose sleep on creating value, not valuation.

~ Deep Kalra

How To Overcome Writer's Block:

#1. Turn your creativity into a habit

- Set a writing routine: write at fixed hours and in a fixed place everyday.

#2. Note down all your outpouring of ideas on the good days

- Revisit them when you're out of ideas.

#3. Ditch the beginning

- Write the body of the article. Or the conclusion. Get yourself in the zone.

#4. Read other people's content

- Rewrite it with your own ideas. (Don't copy!)

7 Tips To Enjoy The Holiday Season As A Freelancer:

1. Share your availability with your clients.

2. Ask your clients about their availability.

3. Give your clients deadlines for "ordering" new work.
For eg. "For any new work, please message me by 15th December, so I may complete the work before I take a break."

4. Spend 1-2 every single day, including holidays, on work.
This will reduce the stress of resuming work from a standstill after the holidays.

5. Focus on prospecting.
You are losing 2 weeks' worth of prospecting this month, so focus on it for the first 2-3 weeks of December.

6. Close deals for January, and get paid in advance to book your time.
This will help you keep up with the momentum of your work and income.

7. Protip: You may offer new clients a 5-10% discount for booking you 1 month in advance.

And finally, enjoy your holidays guilt-free!

Wishing everyone an amazing December... work hard and party hard!

#ShreyaWrites

~ Leonard Bernstein

8 Things You Must Mention In Your Contract:

1. Scope of work
- What services are included, and what are not

2. Fees
- Mention the breakdown, total fees, and any discounts offered

3. Process of working
- Indicate your work-hours, times you are available for calls, how you will submit the work, etc

4. The final deliverables
- Content on a Google Doc?
- Graphic designs?
-Publish content on website?

5. Timeline
- On what day(s) will you submit the work? Until when will you offer edits?

6. Number of edits
- â€œUp to x additional edits will be provided per piece of content.â€

7. Byline
- Are you getting the credits, or is it ghostwriting?

8. Payment terms
- How should you be paid, what percentage of the amount, and on what date?

Of course, do include any other term(s) specific to you and your work.

11 ways to handle (offensive) criticism:

1. Develop a thick skin; most criticisms donâ€™t need your response.

2. Avoid psychoanalysing the person criticising you [â€œOh they must be going through something really badâ€]

3. Stop giving attention to criticism and focus solely on yourself and your goals.

4. Understand the nuances of criticism: feedback, critique, unsolicited criticism, sarcasm, abuses and insults. Ignore most of them.

5. Periodically cleanse your social media accounts of people that drain your energy.

6. Work on yourself. If 99% comments are positive and only 1% of negative comments agitate you, then you need to work on yourself.

7. Have the ability to laugh at past criticism. It gives us the courage to handle new criticism that may come our way.

8. Make allowances for your own and other personâ€™s communication & contextual gaps.

9. Profit from criticism. Let the criticism fire you up to excel!

10. Accept that criticism is the digital exhaust of your social media engine.

11. Avoid making enemies out of strangers.

How do you handle criticism?

#ShreyaWrites

~ Orrin Woodward

1. Create a structure. Then let your thoughts flow and write it all down.

2. Edit dispassionately and ruthlessly. You may have written an amazing line, but if it doesnâ€™t belong here, edit it.

3. Emulate the style of your favourite writers. Check what works for them, and weave that style into your own writing.

4. Be open to feedback/ critique. Listen to any feedback you receive, even if youâ€™re not going to work on it now.

5. Type out your favourite novel into a document. Elliot Chan typed out The Great Gatsby (47,000 words!) to understand the writerâ€™s thoughts, choice of words and writing mechanics.

6. Identify what aspect of writing YOU want to improve upon, and look for resources suited for you.

What would you add to this list?

Read your content,
And after every sentence,

Keep the sentence.

Editing done!

Pro-tip for invoicing:

If you have negotiated with your client,
Mention that negotiated rate as a discount in your invoice.

Example:
Original rate = INR 10,000/-
Negotiated rate = INR 8,000/-

In your invoice, write:
INR 10,000
Less: discount @ 20%
-----------
INR 8,000

Benefits:

1. The client is aware of your original value and negotiation.
2. If the client is long-term and it comes to renewing the rates, your invoices will be an easy, indisputable reminder of the original rates.

Have you ever done this?

#ShreyaWrites

â€œIâ€™m too young to start... â€

â€œI am young & donâ€™t know what I want to do...â€

â€œIâ€™m a student. Iâ€™ll start after graduation...â€


I strongly believe there is an unmatched power & sure-shot advantage in starting young.

When we start young, we start from ZERO, with not much to lose (other than our ego.)

When we start young, we can EXPERIMENT with 100 different things and find out the few things we are good at, & passionate about.

When we start young, we can work on MULTIPLE things at the same time since our other priorities are not as big.

When we start young, we gain EXPERIENTIAL knowledge & soft skills, which we keep honing with time.

When we start young, we can readily get HELP from friends, family & experts.

When we start young, we can afford to make MISTAKES & get away with most of them.

When we start young, we accumulate more years of real experience, giving us an undue ADVANTAGE that keeps compounding.


Should we figure everything out when we are young & look for guarantees?
No.

Should we start young & give ourselves the chance we deserve?
Yes!

When did you start?

#ShreyaWrites

P.S. The wider the range of possibilities we offer children, the more intense will be their motivations and the richer their experiences.

~ Loris Malaguzzi

Long drives taught me copywriting!

Sitting in the passenger's seat, I would read out the billboards whizzing by.

Sometimes, I would read one & tell my dad,
"That's so clever"

Other times I would say,
"The text is poorly aligned, I can't make any sense of it."

Soon this became a habit.

"Wow, that really stands out"
"Why is their text yellow? I can't even see it"
"Is that an appropriate message by a brand?"

I did this for various kinds of ads: cars, insurance schemes, coffee powder, residential buildings...

Without realising, I was honing my copywriting skills & designing sensibilities.

This proved useful when I started writing ads.

I knew what to and what not to write,
I knew what the graphic should look like.

Now, when new writers ask me how to learn copywriting, I say:

1. Check existing ads (billboards, newspapers, social media)
2. Learn from the ads - why did they write that?
3. Improve upon the ads - what could they have done better?

The best part? As a newbie writer, you can also add some of your best suggestions to your portfolio!

What've you learnt through random daily activities?

#ShreyaWrites

P.S. It is not enough to be in the right place at the right time. You should also have an open mind at the right time.

~ Paul ErdÅ‘s

I resumed gym last weekâ€¦

Before the lockdown, I had been working out consistently.

Last week, I resumed working out at the gym.

I knew I was going to struggle with lifting heavy weights and I was mentally prepared to start from scratch.

Then, I was surprised...

I was able to lift the weight just fine,
But I was unable to grip the dumbbells.

Gripping a light, 2kg dumbbell was also painful.

I persisted,
And managed to hit bare minimum reps.

It took me a few days, and my grip â€” the foundation of any workout â€” is now steadily improving.

This â€œgripâ€ applies to everything.

Discontinuity or a long break takes us back to where we started.

Be it
writing,
baking,
posting on LinkedIn, etc.

We may still be really good at those things, but what weâ€™ve lost is the grip.

To get the grip back, we need to resume the task itself.

We need to make it through the inertia & pain and be committed to the task.

How do you get your grip back?

#ShreyaWrites

P.S. I hated every minute of training, but I said, 'Don't quit. Suffer now and live the rest of your life as a champion.'

~ Muhammad Ali

What Apple taught me about pricing...

I broke my phone a few days ago.

The next morning, I went to the store.

I looked around and found the phone that suited my requirements.

Then, I had 3 options:
1. 64 GB (â‚¬ X)
2. 256 GB (â‚¬ X + 170)
3. 512 GB (â‚¬ X + 400)

Without thinking much, I went for the second option: 256 GB.

Why?
1. 64 GB was too less for me
2. There was no option for 128 GB
3. The only sensible choice was 256 GB, even if that meant paying more.

And thatâ€™s exactly why Apple did not create the 128 GB model. Because thatâ€™s the intermediate - one that EVERYONE would go for.

So, by skipping the 128 GB option, Apple made our decision for us.

How can you apply this pricing strategy to your business?

#ShreyaWrites

How to charge for content writing?

Per #word

Benefits:
- Get paid for exactly what you write

Challenges:
- No advance payment
- Uncertain final word count, hence unpredictable pay

Per #hour

Benefits:
- Helpful when the scope of work is not clearly defined
- Possibility of advance payment for a certain number of hours

Challenges:
- Hourly rates turn into large numbers quickly
- Client may not be prepared for large numbers & hence renegotiate later.

Per #project

Benefits:
- Full advance payment possible
- Income clearly defined

Challenges:
- Pressure to complete the task
- More responsibility & accountability towards content quality & delivery.

So, how do you plan to charge?

#ShreyaWrites

P.S. Competing with everyone: $10/hr
Competing with a few: $100/hr
Selling a product: $1,000/hr
Building equity: $10,000/hr
Making a market: $100,000/hr

~ Sahil Lavingia

Writing is like cycling.

You canâ€™t learn cycling by reading about it.

The number of hours you spend reading about cycling is irrelevant...

Until you START cycling.

You fall down,
You scrape your elbows & knees,
You get hurt...

But if you keep at it, eventually, you will learn to balance well.

Thatâ€™s how you learn cycling... and writing.

Writing can be improved only by writing.

Yes, the fundamentals like grammar & vocabulary may be learnt through reading.

But if you want to improve writing, practice it.

For every hour of reading, spend at least 10 hours writing.

If you need inspiration, read for 15-20 minutes and then start writing.

Eventually you wonâ€™t need an external inspiration to write.

Of course, reading for learning, academics and enjoyment have a different context.

But if you want to improve a skill, be consistent in DOING and practising, rather than just reading.

#ShreyaWrites

P.S. Knowledge is the beginning of practice; doing is the completion of knowing.

~ Wang Yangming

Once, there lived a little boy.

He found a seed.

He planted it & dreamed of savouring the mangoes it would yield.

Days passed.
So did weeks, months, and years.

Then... a little ball, as crimson as the hue of the dawning sun, hung on the once-little-tree's branch.

The boy, not-so-little anymore, spotted this sphere from a few feet below.

He climbed the branches,
Met a few ants & cobwebs,
Caught hold of the fruit,
And huddled back down.

As soon as his feet touched the soft grass, he expected to see a mango in his hand.

It was an orange.

He was shattered. He was angry.

Instantly, he hated the tree.

He wanted to get rid of it so he wouldn't be reminded of his foolishness.

He lifted his axe and began chopping down the tree.

He kept thinking how the tree had deceived him.

He got angry & upset, and kept swinging his axe.

Then, it struck him:
The tree wasn't a mango tree at all.
It was an orange tree.

No amount of care or love could make an orange tree grow mangoes.

He let down the axe.

He brought some water, nurtured the tree again.

And finally, he learnt to savour the sweetness of an orange.

#ShreyaWrites

Lesson? Appreciate what it is, than dream of what it could have been.

#content #writer #contentwriter

23rd December, 2012

â€œCompetitionâ€

Competition - a way to prove oneself better
Something upon which living matters

How would you rebuild your ship in the middle of the sea?

Imagine this:

Youâ€™re on a wooden ship, in the middle of the sea.

Suddenly, you are required to rebuild the ship.

How would you do that?

You cannot start from the bottom, of course.

So you pull out a beam and instantly replace it with another beam.

You do this, while using the rest of the ship as a support system.

And you keep doing this, step-by-step, until you have rebuilt the entire ship.

This is how philosopher Otto Neurath describes our belief system.

We can change our beliefs bit by bit, and keep replacing them with new beliefs.

Slowly, our entire system is rebuilt. And we have a new belief system.

Why is this important for business?

Because when you persuade your client to close a deal, you shouldnâ€™t give them a heap of reasons to believe in you.

Instead, focus your message, and give them the main reasons why YOU are the right person for the work.

Change their belief in you... one step at a time.

#ShreyaWrites

P.S. You never change things by fighting the existing reality. To change something, build a new model that makes the existing model obsolete.

~ Buckminster Fuller

STOP glorifying failure!

Failure is a part of your journey to success.

Failure is normal.

BUT

Glorifying failure is NOT okay.

Itâ€™s not okay to share your failures and console yourself by saying:

â€œI failed, but am proud to have reached so farâ€¦â€
â€œI failed, but I learntâ€¦â€
â€œItâ€™s okay to failâ€¦â€

It's not okay because:

1. Glorifying your failure makes you comfortable with failing
- Accepting failure is good, but being okay with it is not.

2. Glorifying your failure makes you defensive
- Yes, not everything can be controlled; but not everything is out of your control either.

3. Glorifying your failure makes you feel accomplished without winning
- If you are proud of your failures, why would you want to chase success?

So, accept your failures. Be proud of your successes.

And stop glorifying failure.

~ Paulo Coelho

Should you get paid less for your own byline?

In 2017, I applied to 11 premier universities for my Bachelors.

I got into 10.

For any university application, the following 3 things are critical:
1. Application form
2. Letter of recommendation (LOR)
3. Statement of purpose (SOP)

The application forms were straightforward.

Letters of recommendation were given to me by my teachers and employers.

The â€˜make it or break itâ€™ feature was my Statement of Purpose.

A good SOP is one which:
1. Tells your story
2. Exhibits your personality
3. Narrates your achievements (and lessons)
4. Shares your future goals.

Basically, a Statement of Purpose tells the, well, purpose of your life.

Again, a good SOP is also:
1. Succinct
2. Cohesive
3. Persuasive
4. Emotional.

Keep these things in mind, and begin writing!

Remember: A good SOP takes days, weeks, months to write (and rewrite.) Give it the time it deserves.

Have questions? Comment below!

#ShreyaWrites

The art of engaging as a brand...

A brand gets different responses/ comments:

1. Appreciative
2. Provocative and abusive
3. Critical/feedback-oriented.

How to respond in each case:

1. Thank them for their appreciation.

2. Engage only if you can leave an empathetic imprint. Else avoid.

3. For critical/feedback-oriented comments, follow these steps:

â€” i. Begin with empathy:
"We are sorry you had to face this issue, [name]."

â€” ii. Provide your solution:
"Please drop us an email at xxx and we will look into this issue."

â€” iii. Offer to help:
"If you have any questions/concerns, please message us and we'll help you out."

â€” iv. Be grateful:
"Thanks for choosing us!"

#Eg., if my brand SNB sold a notebook and got a comment from Pooja that the pages were stained, I would respond:

"We are sorry you had to face this issue, Pooja. Please raise a complaint at SNBdotcom and our team will help you with the best solution. If you have any other concerns, please write to us. Thanks for choosing SNB!"

As a brand, be humane.
Be empathetic.

How you make people FEEL is what sticks with your brand.

#ShreyaWrites

I NEVER charge per word.

[Reposting this since pricing services is a dilemma!]

Quoting a price is much more than finance. It is all about the human psyche. It's about understanding how the mind perceives information.

Suppose I quote "INR 8 per word for a 400-word blog*".

Here's what happens:

1. This statement starts a tedious process of calculation in the reader's mind

2. The reader starts multiplying 400 with 8, and starts worrying about the number of digits in the end result

3. It makes the reader compare my charge to the value of one word, than the overall article (1 word= INR 8??? Oh my God!)

4. It creates the perception that I am charging TOO high for content.

BUT...

When I quote "INR 3,200 for a 400-word blog*", the game changes.

Then:

1. The brain is spared of calculations where 2 small numbers create a much larger one

2. The reader considers the overall amount being paid for the value of a complete article.

A blog is much more than a set of words put together. So why charge per word?

Charge for the #value you provide.

#ShreyaWrites

P.S. *the mentioned prices are for example only :)

#content #writer #contentwriter

What's the plural of 'aircraft'?

Ready with your answer?

3

2

1

'Aircraft'!

Yes, the plural of 'aircraft' is 'aircraft'.

The word 'aircraft' is an irregular plural.

An irregular plural does not follow the rule of adding an 's' to pluralise a word.

More examples:
Fish
Deer
Sheep

Do you know any more irregular plurals? Comment!

How to make money without spending money...

Donâ€™t meet people.

Yes.
Donâ€™t travel.
Donâ€™t meet people.

The best part of freelancing is that itâ€™s remote.

The best part of living in 2019 is that everything can be remote.

You donâ€™t need to spend time or money to close deals.

Skip the formal dress up. Skip the traffic. Skip the wait.

Do this:

1. Get a basic brief from the prospect on email/text

2. Speak to the prospect over a 30-minute call
- Discuss their requirement
- Answer queries
- Ask doubts

3. Think whether you both are a good fit for each other

4. Send a proposal to the prospect

5. Answer any queries on a follow-up call of 15-30 mins

6. Send a contract, get it approved and signed

7. Set up longer calls if needed to discuss the details of the work.

Hereâ€™s what you spend: 1.5 hours.
- 1 hour on 2 calls
- 30 minutes making/ sending the proposal

If you use an app (WhatsApp, Zoom, Skype) for a call, the call itself is practically free.

Drop the travel.

Save your time and money while you earn (save) more.

â€˜Each new paragraph starts abruptly.â€™

To improve on this aspect of my essay writing, I met my Trinity professor.

She said, â€œMake it messy.â€

- Start with a draft that is all over the place.

- Throw in quotes, references and ideas randomly.

- Think, think out aloud, and type it out.

- And when you have done it all, make an outline and fit in the essentials.

If you start with a mess,

- you will be more critical of your own work

- you will be willing to move things around until they are in the right place.

But:
If you start with an essay-like flow that looks â€˜beautifulâ€™, you wonâ€™t want to move things around... because there are no things left to move around!

And this has nothing to do with language or writing skills.

Itâ€™s all about craftsmanship.

Itâ€™s all about how the writing is perceived.

Perception rules.

"Shreya, we love your work. Please go through this company profile and edit it. It's just a matter of 10 mins..."

I had just submitted my first blog to a client, when I got this response.

He had paid the advance promptly.

I checked the document of the company profile.

It was 2 pages long in font size 9.

I reviewed the work and quoted my fee.

He responded with many appreciative words, praising my approach and work, only to conclude that he was 'not sold.'

Seems pretty normal right?

Watch out for:

1. Too much praise too soon
- It was just 1 blog!

2. Unwarranted praise
- Flattery, only to ignore/dismiss everything you say/do.

3. Undervaluing work
- "just a matter of 10 mins", "a simple edit", "it's not hard", "whip something up"... constantly belittling your work.

But, he had made the payment on time... that's all that matters, right?

Wrong!

Soon, he questioned all the work I did.

He brought up issues on things that he had already signed and agreed upon.

Eventually, he broke the contract halfway.

Lesson? Timely payment does not entitle a client to freebies.

Donâ€™t get manipulated by appreciation.

Fake appreciation cannot replace payment.

#ShreyaWrites

P.S. You are rich only when you are willing to walk away from the money!

I won every poem recitation competition for 4 years... for the same poem!

It all started when I was in the first grade.

I had my first ever poem recitation competition.

As usual, I made my own list of common poems and took it to my dad.

My dad got up, went to the huge 'library' in my room, took out a book of poems and flipped some pages.

He stopped at the page with the poem "The Tyger" by William Blake.

He read the poem out to me, stressing on the words that the 6-year-old me would have mispronounced: 'thine', 'sinews', 'dread'.

For a week, I sat with the poem, memorising it stanza by stanza.

On the day of the competition, I took my toy tiger to school and set it on the table next to me while reciting the poem.

I won first place in the whole of first grade.

By this time, I had fallen in love with 'The Tyger' and refused to give it up.

I recited it again and again and again for 3 more years, and won first place each time.

And that's what my childhood was based on: a fearfully symmetrical 'Tyger'.

Happy Children's Day!

#ShreyaWrites

"Iâ€˜ll try to wake up earlyâ€
"Iâ€˜ll try to go to the gym 3 times a week"

By saying 'try', you are preparing for failure.

You are conditioning yourself to be comfortable with failure.

Either you give your everything, or you don't.

Either you put in all your effort, or you don't.

As Yoda says, "Do. Or do not. There is no try."

Word 2: 'At least'

Why I stopped using this word: Life made me do it.

"At least I slept on time even if I didn't wake up early"
"At least I went to the gym once a week"
"At least I tried..."

Saying 'at least' is a consolation. A pacification.

â€˜At leastâ€™ makes you lower your standard instead of raising the bar.

It's one thing to look at the bright side and work harder next time.

It's another to justify not doing something by explaining the minimum you did.

So yes, I do not use these two words anymore.

I mean, at least I try not to!
;)

#ShreyaWrites

P.s. I only pick tasks where I give my 100%. Understanding the task becomes identifying the process. The more you are aware of the process, the more you control the end results.

Not to be pessimistic or optimistic but to be poetic ;)

In his recent post, Diptesh Das asked how email copy works...

Here's something to get you started:-

There are 4 important elements to email copy:

1. The subject line
2. The first line of the email
3. The structure of the body
4. The 'P.S.' after the signature (this is done by all excellent copywriters).

These are the features of a good email copy:

1. Be to the point. Very, very essential.
2. Use simple words and short sentences.
3. Use bullet points, headings, subheadings; make it easy to skim through.
4. Build a story around your product/service offering. Explain your pain points that the reader will resonate with, then give your solution.
5. Make it conversational.
6. Present your solution as an experience, not a 'features of this product' list.

That's all there is!

The rest? It's trial and error.

Once you send the emails out, you'll know what to do better.

Emails of different purposes are written differently. You'll pick that up with time.

Don't think about perfecting the email copy, just get started!

#ShreyaWrites
