Why do you follow me?

#ShreyaWrites

When I write, nothing else exists.

I sit at the desk and turn my laptop on.

I open the document and start typing.

At first, I have no thoughts. I don't know what I am doing.

In a few minutes, I understand what I am supposed to do.

I begin to focus on my work.

20 minutes in, I am completely immersed into my work.

Suddenly, writing feels so effortless. So natural.

I write without thinking too much. It all just flows out.

At this point, I feel in control.

I know I am taking this piece of writing in the direction I want to take it.

Now, I am lost in my writing.

I cannot hear any sound around me. I cannot hear anyone call my name.

Now, I have no sense of time.

How long have I been writing? I don't know. Maybe 13 mins, maybe 7 hours.

Now, I am done. My work is complete.

It's dark outside. I have skipped lunch yet again.

This is so rewarding. Time for a well-deserved dinner.
...
As per Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, this is my 'flow.'

Flow is the state of timelessness, undivided attention, mental peace, and accomplishment, where everything ceases to exist.

When are YOU in the flow?

#ShreyaWrites

â€œI got into universities in Ireland and UK, which do you suggest is better?â€

Many students hit my inbox with this question.

Of course, college decisions are based on many factors; one of the most important being location.

It is easy to decide between two entirely different countries, say, the US and UK.

But when UK and Ireland are so close by (and similar in some ways), there are deeper questions involved.

Hereâ€™s why I chose Ireland over UK:

1. Dual degree
â€” Trinity is the only college that offers a dual degree for the same annual fee as for one subject (I'm pursuing English & Philosophy.)

2. 4-year bachelors'
â€” Ireland has a 4-year BA like the US; UK has a 3-year BA like India. Certain colleges require a 4-year bachelors' to apply for a Masters programme; so I chose Ireland.

3. Brexit
â€” Simply put, the Republic of Ireland is independent of the UK. This has led big companies to open up offices in Ireland, creating more job opportunities.

4. Visa
â€” The Irish visa offered me the option to work in Ireland after completing my degree, unlike the UK visa.

BUT... UK now offers a 2 year work visa after graduation. That changes a lot of decisions!

What do you think is the most important part of making college decisions?

I won a tongue-twister competition in school because my dad said, "Say it slowly".

I was 6 years old at the time.

Our school announced a competition to 'recite' a tongue-twister.

I went home and waited all day for my dad to come back from office.

As soon as he entered the door, I told him about the competition.

I had a list of tongue-twisters written in a double-lined notebook.
I read them out to him in a super-fast tongue-twisting speed.

After I was done, my dad took my notebook and wrote a tongue-twister in it. I took a deep breath and was ready to read it fast, when my dad stopped me.

My dad said, "Read it slow."

I found that absurd. It's a tongue-twister... it's meant to be said fast!

He repeated, "Read it slow. Be clear when you talk."

I listened to him and memorised the tongue-twister.

In class, all the other students who spoke before me went fast. I started to wonder whether it would be okay if I didn't do that.

When it was my turn, I did what I was prepared for: I spoke at a normal pace; slow and clear.

And... I won first place!

I am still not sure what 'worked'.

What I do know is:
Speaking clearly worked.
Standing out worked.
Listening to my dad worked.

#ShreyaWrites

I totally blanked out in an interview this week...

Earlier this week, I had a group interview for a role in college.

Excited to have been shortlisted for this very competitive role, this interview was very important to me.

I reached 15 mins early for the interview and eagerly waited in the hallway. Soon I was called into the interview room along with 4 more girls.

The format was simple: each person in the group would be asked a question one-by-one.

The questions were interesting and I answered the first two rounds well.

Then, something happened in the final round.

The interviewer asked me a question.
I thought of the perfect answer.

And just as I was about to start speaking...
I went blank.

Totally blank.
My mind froze.

What was happening?!

After a few seconds, I managed to answer the question.

Later, I came out of the room, disappointed in myself.

As I walked back home, I wondered what happened to me. It had never happened before; why did it now?

That's when I realised: I'd only slept 4 hours the previous night.

Just four hours.
And that is not at all okay.

That day, I learnt my lesson.

I may make it through my day with less sleep, but I won't be able to function to my fullest potential.

Reminder: sleep well.

#ShreyaWrites

"I wrote a very good blog with SEO in mind, but it didn't get any views..."

Everyday I get such a message from writers, and also people who've hired writers.

So...
You wrote a very good blog? Yes.

Did you market your blog? *crickets chirping*

A few things:-

1. No one is going to look for exactly the same topic that you published.

2. Your blog needs ENGAGEMENT to rank better, not SEO keywords.

3. Your blog won't be seen unless you show it to a few people, who will then show it to more.

Published a blog?
SHOW IT OFF!

1. Share the link on social media: even WhatsApp stories!

2. Post the first two paragraphs as a LinkedIn article and write "Click here to read more..." Direct people to your website.

3. Cross-link! Mention the link of a guest's blog on your blog, and let them mention yours on theirs. Win-win situation!

4. Talk about it. Create the hype. Share posts with context, and end them with 'new blog coming out this Friday'.

5. Start a newsletter, and use your social media, especially LinkedIn, to get sign-ups.

Do one, do two, or do all: MARKET YOUR BLOG.

(Psst: detailed article about interview essentials coming out on 28th September)

See what I did there?

#ShreyaWrites

â€” â€˜Tell us something about yourselfâ€™ is simple, yet very tricky. Your introduction matters most.

5. Eagerness
â€” how promptly/enthusiastically you respond shows what you really want

6. Questions
â€¨â€” your questions help us gauge your interests, skills and prior research.

"I am running a business!!!"

Until a few months ago, I would heavily negotiate with my prospects.

I would quote my price, then the prospects would quote theirs.
In the fear of losing them, I would say okay.

Then one day while I was in a mall, I saw a handbag with a price tag of INR 15,000. Next to it was a similar bag of another brand, with a tag of INR 3,000.

That's when I realised:
> When I go shopping and see a price tag, I can't negotiate with the cashier.

> I can't negotiate just because I am buying 3 handbags.

> I can't negotiate just because I visited their store every week.

So why should I negotiate for content?

THAT was my turning point.

I stopped negotiating.

3 things I like about a job:

1. Routine
â€” I leave from home, and get back home at the same time everyday. My work hours are fixed, Mondays to Fridays.

â€” I need to reach office at a fixed time, and finish the work before the clock hits six.

â€” I've always had amazing people in my team, who have been honest with feedback, and encouraging too!

3 things I like about freelancing:

â€” I decide when, where and how I want to work. Most importantly, I decide WHO I want to work with.

2. I avoid the daily commute
â€” ... which means more time for finding clients, pitching, and working.

3. Potential for more income
â€” It takes time, dedication and hard work... and with the right mix, there's a lot of potential here!

Both, full-time job and freelancing, have their own perks.

The first time I drove a car, I messed up BAD.

I'd just received my driver's license.

When we planned to visit a relative, I volunteered to take the wheel for the 30km drive.

My dad sat in the passenger's seat, guiding me.

Halfway through the drive, we were on an uphill curved road.

I wasn't thinking straight, and ended up putting the car in the wrong gear. The car screeched loud & almost stalled; with a huge truck honking right behind us.

I changed the gear quickly and drove a little further.

In that moment, I panicked.

I panicked so much, I decided to let my dad drive for the rest of the way.

I was ready to stop, when my dad said, "It's okay, drive."

I told him I didn't want to drive anymore.

He said it again: "Drive. You are in that seat now, drive all the way through..."

I drove... slow, taking my time.

I made it all the way.

A few days later, I drove again: better this time.

That's when I realised the importance of my first drive.

If I would have let my dad finish the drive, I would have lost the confidence to start a new one.

If I would have given up, I wouldn't know what to improve on.

Lesson? If you have taken the driver's seat, complete the journey.

It may take time, let it.
Complete it.

Enjoy it!

#ShreyaWrites

There are some comments I wish I hadn't read at all.

With time, I have learnt to ignore such people and focus on the positive.

I have learnt that haters are inevitable. There will always be such people around. The more I grow, the more such people I will find.

But as I see more and more content on LinkedIn, I also see more and more haters.

So, I think this is important to be said: Be kind online.

There's a real person on the other side of the screen, who reads your comments and remembers them.

Before you attack someone, think how one comment of yours can affect their life.

Feel free to share your opinions and present your arguments. Please don't forget to be kind.

This is an online world where every word counts.
Make sure it is kind.

"INR 200 ($2.8) per article... we give topic, you just write"

A few weeks ago, I shared how I was asked to write a 1000-word article for INR 450 (~$6.5).

Today, I received an offer for $2.8!

When I told the lady about my charges, she responded:
"We give topic you just write".

The response spun my world around!

I thought, 'Umm... did she miss a '0' in the end?'

Then I realised, people truly don't know what goes into 'just' writing.

Dear Prospects,

This is what we writers do for hours and hours and hours:
1. Research
2. Further research
3. Write first draft
4. Edit
5. Edit again, and again, and again
6. Proofread
7. Edit again based on feedback
8. Submit final content.

Please remember:

1. Pay minimum Re. 1 per word.

2. Continuous work does not allow for less pay.
The time, effort and creativity is the same for each piece, why must the pay be less?

3. Writing pays our bills.

Pay well.
Value words.
Respect writers.

Nike's logo designer was paid $2 (~â‚¹ 130) per hour!

That's right.

In 1971, Carolyn Davidson designed Nike's logo for just $35 (today itâ€™s $221).She was a college student.

Her brief for the logo? It must convey motion and differ from Adidas.

After designing for 17.5 hours, Carolyn came up with the 'Swoosh' logo that conveyed motion and agility.

Although we love the 'Swoosh' logo today, Carolyn's designs were repeatedly rejected when she first made it.

In fact, she was so fed up of the rejections, that she just submitted her design and gave up.

Finally, Nike ended up going with Carolyn's design.

12 years later, Nike boomed BIG.

Nike's owner, Knight, knew that the logo was one of the key reasons for the company's success.

As a gift to Carolyn, Knight gave her 500 shares of the company in 1983.

Today, her shares are valued for thousands of dollars!

And that's how a $35 logo turned into a million dollar success (for Carolyn and Nike)!

So... what's the lesson here?

1. Rejections are natural, and happen to the best of people

2. Do the best you can, repeatedly

3. Always value your own creativity

4. JUST DO IT.

#ShreyaWrites

"My post has high engagement of 25,000 views, but I didn't get any leads..."

I get this message often that a post got so many views, but it didn't help the person generate leads.

First, picture this:

1. You walk by a chocolate store
2. You like how big and attractive the store is
3. You stop and enter the chocolate store
4. You explore the store, inquire about the chocolates
5. You buy a chocolate, or leave the store with a pamphlet.

The number of views you get is the number of people who walked by (scrolled past) your post.

The engagement is the number of people who liked the first few lines of your post, explored it, and, liked, commented and shared it.

Now, remember this: Number of views is not engagement!

Likes, comments, shares and direct messages are engagement.

So... how do you get more engagement on your LinkedIn posts?

The Facebook ads.
The billboards and hoardings.

3. Observe the content around you, and think how youâ€™d make it better.

4. Emulate (not copy!) this content.

5. Create content from scratch.

There is no perfect course. Don't spend time looking for one.
You just need to write!

"Shreya, how much should I charge...?"

Here are 3 important factors to consider while charging for different forms of content:

1. Blogs
- i. Niche
- ii. Word count
- iii. Research required

2. Social media posts
- i. Number of posts
- ii. Social media handles + nature of posts
- iii. Graphic designing involved?

3. Website
- i. Number of webpages
- ii. Content density on each webpage
- iii. Edit draft content/ write from scratch?

4. Presentations
- i. Number of slides
- ii. Designing of slides?
- iii. Time needed (content + images/ icons + designing)

Always consider the resources involved, especially your time. If something is research-heavy and requires a lot of time, charge more.

Charge worth the work and work every minute.
And of course, deliver awesome quality work.

Need pricing details for any other forms of content?
Comment, and I'll answer that for you!

"Hi Shreya, thanks for the reminder, had missed out on replying..."

I had emailed 3 prospects about 2 weeks ago.

For 2 weeks, I didn't hear back from them.

So I dropped them a reminder, and they said they would get back to me in 2-3 days.

I waited for 3 days, and received no response.

I did not want to seem too pushy, and I did not want to spend time on a deal that seemed unlikely. So I did not email them.

On the 5th day, I thought it was worth a shot to drop a short 'I am waiting' reminder email. After all, I had nothing to lose.

So, I emailed all 3 people.

And I am now working with 2 of them.

Sometimes people genuinely miss out on replying to your emails.

Although follow-ups may seem aggressive or too persistent, you must do it a few times.

If they still don't reply, you can take the decision to move on to other prospects.

But: if someone has genuinely forgotten to reply, this follow-up email will restart the conversation.

Following up is a very important aspect of pitching.
Do it.

I chose the more painful surgery option for long term benefits...

I recently underwent an eye surgery for vision correction.

I had two major options:
1. LASIK
2. PRK Laser

Both options involve different procedures: the cornea is treated differently.

Option 1: It is the latest procedure. The recovery is majorly painless, and vision is restored within a day.

Option 2: It is the first ever laser eye surgery. It requires a painful 2-day healing time, and needs upto 10 days to restore clear vision.

I chose the second surgery option.

Why?

Because: To me, the long term benefits mattered more than the instant gratification.

My goal was not just to regain my sight instantly.
My goal was to regain the best possible sight for years to come.

I experienced a lot of discomfort for 3 days.

But I kept saying to myself, "This pain is just for now. It's going to be over, and you will be grateful for your decision."

My point is this: sometimes, to get the most out of something, you have to give up comfort.

When it comes to your career, passion, personal happiness; anything at all: the initial struggles need to be faced. Bravely.

The best things demand sacrifices.

Know when to make those sacrifices.

You will thank yourself later.

#ShreyaWrites

"Hey Shreya, how much should I charge for #content?"

There is no 'perfect' price for content.

If you are starting out, here are some basic factors to consider for pricing:

- Niche
- Number of words
- Frequency of work
- Nature of work (are you writing from scratch, do you get a draft, will you be outsourcing any work, etc)
- Research involved
- Time needed
- Taxes
- Company position [yes, this matters]
- Fussy clients [yes, this matters too!]
- Minimum monthly income through content writing.

How to use these factors:
- Bulk work? Offer discounted rates
- Less time? Increase rates
- Lot of research? Increase rates...

Consider all these factors and chart out a suitable fee.

Questions? Comment!

#ShreyaWrites

[Psst... "10 Tips for Starting Out as a Content Writer" coming out soon]

"WHAT IS SHE DOING???"

(My hostel horror story)

Last year, I moved to Dublin for college.

I was living in a hostel for the first time, sharing a room with someone I had never met before!

One night, I was sitting on my bed, quietly working on my laptop.

The sun had set completely, and it was pitch black outside.

Suddenly, I heard a horrifying sound...

The horrifying sound of... NAILS BEING CUT!

I completely freaked out! I screamed at my roommate in my head, "What is she doing???"

Since I was a child, I have never cut my nails after sundown.

Seeing my roommate cut her nails at this hour was truly shocking!

At that very minute I realised how different cultures are across the world.

One thing we aren't ever taught in school or told about is how to understand, respect and accept different traditions.

This small incident taught me how to be open to all unique and contrasting cultures, and not be startled by them.

Psst... I did speak to my roommate about this, and yes, we had a nice laugh!

A truly horrifying night it was!

#ShreyaWrites

Saying your expenses are high does not permit you to 'save' on content. Content should be a part of your #budget.

The next time you strategise your business plan, INCLUDE content.

#Content is a HUGE deal. Hell, it is THE deal.

I NEVER charge per word.

Quoting a price is much more than finance. It is all about the human #psyche. It's about understanding how the mind perceives information.

Suppose I quote "INR 8 per word for a 400-word blog*".

Here's what happens:

1. This statement starts a tedious process of calculation in the reader's mind

2. The reader starts multiplying 400 with 8, and starts worrying about the number of digits in the end result

3. It makes the reader compare my charge to the value of one word, than the overall article (1 word= INR 8??? Oh my God!)

4. It creates the perception that I am charging TOO high for #content.

BUT...

When I quote "INR 3,200 for a 400-word blog*", the game changes.

Then:

1. The brain is spared of calculations where 2 small numbers create a much larger one

2. The reader considers the overall amount being paid for the value of a complete #article.

A #blog is much more than a set of words put together. So why charge per word?

Charge for the #value you provide.

#ShreyaWrites #tips #freelancers

*the mentioned prices are for example only; I charge higher than this :)

"I worked for one whole month, and they paid me Rs. 0"

I met a friend recently who told me about his #internship. He worked from home for a start-up, developing apps and websites for them.

He invested 10 hours each day, 5 days a week, for 1 whole month.

In a month, the start-up changed its Manager. Finally, when it came to the payment, my friend did not get anything.
The new Manager had no previous approval letter with him, and said the company will not be using his work, so they will not pay for the work.

Why did all this happen? Because my friend had no written confirmation #letter.

The job approvals were in an informal manner on WhatsApp.

His 'offer letter' was a simple message: 'Welcome to XYZ'.

There was no written and signed approval stating the work or stipend.

This is a very important lesson, especially for #students:

Do NOT work without a written, signed, stamped #offer #letter which CLEARLY states the work, duration and stipend of the job.

WhatsApp is NOT okay. Written emails are NOT okay.

Make sure you have an original signed and stamped letter posted to you, or a scan over email.

Be aware. Always have proof.

Did you know: 'Alot' is #not a word!

Every day I see comments saying "thanks alot", and I'm surprised when they are used even by #writers!

What is the #correct word?

"A lot"
- This means 'many'
- Eg., "thanks a lot", "I had a lot of fun", "Your post helped me a lot"

"Allot"
- to give a certain amount
- Eg., "I was allotted seat 47", "We're allotted 1 hour of break"

Other words which #sound #similar but have #different #meanings:
- Who's/ Whose
- There/ Their
- Except/ Accept
- Advice/ Advise
- Practice/ Practise

Do you know the difference in the above words? Do you know any more such words? #Comment below!

#ShreyaWrites

A few weeks ago, I wrote about how I #moved #on from an interview.

Before I decide to move on, I take two steps #after any #interview:

1. #Email a â€˜Thank Youâ€™
I write an email to the company #thanking them for the interview, specify which part of our #conversation I liked the most, and ask them to #contact me for any further questions. Such an email makes interviewees #memorable, and may sway any neck-to-neck decisions the interviewer is making.

2. Await a response, #follow #up after said-date
If I havenâ€™t heard back from the company after the said-date, I email them a #reminder. If I don't get a response soon, I follow this up with a #call. If I don't hear back after multiple attempts, I simply #move #on.

Interviews take immense #efforts to catch hold of, and even more so to #crack. It gets draining to let go of #opportunities we think we had. But it's always better to use our #time and #energy working for the #next #interview.

The important thing is to not give up.

The trick is to keep #learning and #keep #going!

I was called out during my #school assembly to #share my #experience with the other #students, a crowd of over 100. I got up and took the mic.

2. Helps you #speak #clear and #align your #thoughts
3. Develops #imagination for the viewer (and yourself!)
4. Creates a #visual #aid through the movement
5. Makes you seem #welcoming and #trustworthy.

So, use your hands; #donâ€™t #hide your gestures.
Let your hands guide you as you speak!

I reviewed CVs this week!

It was so amazing to see how creative and skilled you all are! Most of you nailed the content, and had such awesome CVs! Well done, everyone!

Here are my basic suggestions w.r.t. common errors I found:

1. Keep it only one page long!
2. Use a consistent font. Make it bold or italic as required.
3. The layout must be simple and well-aligned. Don't confuse the reader!
4. Donâ€™t ignore these sections:
-- Short personal summary
-- Soft skills
-- Hobbies/ Interests
-- Personal projects (if any)
-- Volunteering (if any)
5. Personalise your #LinkedIn url! Remove all those numbers from the link, keep it neat, and update it in your CV
6. Spellcheck, spellcheck, spellcheck!
7. Know the difference: its/ itâ€™s, there/their, then/ than
8. Be creative, but donâ€™t make it uncomfortable to read
9. Explain everything! How, why, when, what, how many, what percentâ€¦ use numbers
10. No (unnecessary) short forms!

I hope this helps you improve your #CV!

â€œThink Trinityâ€

These two words were the first two words I came across at a #University fair last year.

I stared at the brochure for a bit, while the representative explained about the Uni.

Honestly, the entire narration was very intimidating. While listening, I gave up the idea of applying here. I was so certain there was no point in hoping to get into such a college, that I decided to not try at all.

I came home with a bunch of brochures and my mom went through them. She opened this one & saw the word â€˜reputationâ€™ and said, â€œThis is where you are goingâ€. (It had nothing to do with the Uni, itâ€™s more of a Taylor Swift thing!) I simply laughed it off; it was silly to think of going here.

Finally, after lots of back & forth, I forwarded my application to the #college. Three weeks later, this miracle happened:-
New email:
#Congratulations, Trinity College Dublin is delighted to #offer you a place...

That is when I realised what the two words meant.

Think.
Think of what you want.
Think of showing up for it.
Think of working for it.
Think of achieving it.

That's where everything starts: in the way you think.
The more it runs in your mind, the more it evolves into you believing it.

And then, you will #do #your #best to have it.

Always #THINK.

6 months since Iâ€™ve been waking up without my dad pulling me out of bed. (Last one is most difficult!)

Well, everything got easier with every passing day. I managed daily commute, falling sick, exam stress, cooking (check out last post for an example), meeting assignment deadlines... everything.

Hereâ€™s a list of little things Iâ€™ve learnt to live by as a student:

1. Follow your instincts!!
2. Be responsible, strong and aware

4. Wear comfortable shoes; be prepared for an unexpectedly long day

7. Wash dishes instantly. The longer you leave them dirty, the harder they are to clean

10. Save money. Track your budget & expenses.

This is how I serve food for myself!

I love cooking. Back at home, I'd cook often for my family, and arrange the food beautifully on a fancy dish.

Now, I cook for myself. I eat by myself. Yet, I plate my food properly even though no one looks at it (sometimes my Instagram does, duh).

Why do I still plate my food nicely?
~ I love cooking, and I like doing it the right way no matter whoâ€™s looking. I believe that things that look good tend to feel good and actually be good.

Why make the efforts when itâ€™s only for myself?
~ A beautiful plate makes me happy, and allows me to appreciate my food better. The efforts arenâ€™t for someone to see; they are for me to enjoy!

Lesson?
If you love something, do your best no matter whoâ€™s looking. Always stand out doing the things you love.

If you love make-up, put on your best winged eyeliner, even if it's only at home!
If you love singing, sing your best, even if itâ€™s only in your bathroom!
If you love writing, write the best email, even if itâ€™s only a product complaint!

Do what you love. And DO IT BEST!

Thank you, Brian Brandt, for making me realise the importance of doing my best for the things I love. Itâ€™s a gem of an advice!

3 Essentials for an Impressive LinkedIn Profile

Don't overlook these when building your profile:

1. Profile picture
- Use a clear, professional image as your profile picture. Keep it natural & don't over-edit it. Avoid selfies, group pictures & filters. If you donâ€™t have a good picture, simply stand in front of a non distracting wall and get it clicked by your friend! Most importantly, make sure the profile picture looks like you!

2. Cover photo
- Donâ€™t overlook this super useful tool! Upload a cover picture that describes your company or your niche or you. This one photo can summarise your entire profile by itself.
Thank you â˜Shontel Burke-Clarke for this awesome tip!

3. Summary
- Use the summary section! Your profile needs an introduction, so use all 2000 characters to talk about you. Share a story or experience to make it interesting. Use headings, subheadings & keywords. Write in bullet points to make it easy to read!

Complete your profile, fill in the important details, and update these 3 things for an amazing profile!

3 Tips for getting a LinkedIn Recommendation

1. Request one!
- To get a recommendation, you must ASK for it! Contact your bosses/ colleagues/ clients etc requesting a LinkedIn recommendation, and also provide them a direct link to make it simple. And make sure you thank them in advance!

2. Highlight key points
- Be specific about what you want the recommender to focus on. This way, you can showcase your strengths & skills more effectively.

3. Ask for corrections
- Your recommendations reflect on you beyond the message. If you see a spelling or punctuation error in the recommendation, donâ€™t hesitate to ask for corrections.

Always strategise your recommendations to your benefit. Make them work for you the way YOU want them to.

Bonus:
1. Use the â€œAsk to Be Recommended Featureâ€
2. Write a recommendation for the recommender too.

Good luck!

3 (FUN) Ways to Improve English:

1. Read, read, read
- Read books, especially classics, to understand how to frame sentences, appropriately use vocabulary, spell correctly, write cohesively, break paragraphs, use punctuation & grammar.
- To develop the habit of reading, start with newspapers/ journals/ magazines at first, eventually move to books.
- Make sure you increase your reading speed & volume every dayâ€” push yourself!

2. Watch English movies & listen to English songs
- While doing these, pay special attention to the pronounciation of the words. Follow the tone, pauses, choice of words, stress on sound etc.
- Referring subtitles & lyrics will help you initially. This is also a good way to understand different accents.

3. Think, converse & write in English
- Thatâ€™s right! Think in English & you will soon start to speak it out loud. Speak to your friends & family in English as well, noticing their use of the language.
-Write moreâ€” journal your day, write emails & texts â€” but avoid â€˜SMSâ€™ language.
- Always write complete sentences to avoid future trouble with spellings, grammar, punctuation, etc.

And of course, ENJOY THE PROCESS!

What are your thoughts on ways to improve English?

- The Ebbinghaus Illusion -

We were discussing the Ebbinghaus Illusion (in pic) in my philosophy class. Suddenly, our professor said, â€˜Not sure what you can do with this information, but it is what it is!â€™ The entire class laughed. I stopped laughing halfway. And in that flash of a second, I knew what my next post would be.

Look at the image below.
Which orange circle looks bigger? Right?

But, both orange circles are of the SAME SIZE!

What happened here?
The grey circles changed our perspective. Our brain compared the orange to the grey circles outside, processed these visual differences & caused us to find the right orange circle bigger.

The things in life are also similar.

Imagine this:
Orange circle- our goal.
Grey circles- our struggles.

When we've small problems: we see our goals BIG & IMPORTANT (& easy to achieve). So we continue to work hard.
When we've big problems: our goals appear small. So we give up on our goal.
Our obstacles, issues, bad timesâ€” they change the importance of our goals & dreams.

In reality, the worth of our ambition is the same.
In reality, both the orange circles are the same.

So, moral of the story?
Donâ€™t let obstacles lessen the importance of your dream. Keep going.

Thoughts?

- Key Aspects of Writing I Learnt with Time (and from my Dad!) -

1. Tell a storyâ€¨
We all love stories, because thatâ€™s what makes any writing personal & relatable. It makes the text interesting, engaging & easy to read.

2. Invoke senses, evoke emotion
We all tend to remember things by our senses and the emotions something made us feel. Iâ€™ve learnt that to be memorable, any writing must be touching, moving & thought-provoking.

3. Use metaphors
If anything works best for writing, it is imagery. Metaphors engage the senses. The use of metaphors lets one show a creative & knowledgable side of themselves, while keeping the reader engrossed & involved.

4. Keep it cohesive
Every line of a paragraph should connect with the next, and with also with the line of the next paragraph. Cohesion gives the writing a flow & keeps the imagination running smoothly, in a sequence.

5. Work on it
Wrote it? Now, edit edit edit! Every piece of writing needs to be worked upon. Be it checking the spelling, grammar, vocabulary, or giving it a complete makeoverâ€” editing is the longest, final & most important step of writing. Editing takes time & one must give it time.

What are your writing tips?

Happy Writing!

- Writing Lessons to Myself -

Itâ€™s been 3 weeks since I shared my experience with LinkedIn's CEO Jeff Weiner. Post that, I started crafting articles, checking post statistics, replying to commentsâ€” never thought Iâ€™d do this for anything other than Instagram!

In the past few days, Iâ€™ve received many messages on how to start writing.

Hereâ€™s my story:

1. I write for myself
Writing has always been my natural way of expressing. I write to share my stories, and I see that people like them!

2. I begin
At times, I sit with a messy idea for hours, other times Iâ€™m lazy. Then, I give myself a goal of 150 words. By the time I stop, Iâ€™ve churned out over 600!

3. Iâ€™m consistent
I write everydayâ€” be it poems, rants or blogs. At first, I scribbled 1 page a day for months; now I see the change. Recently, my writing has been purely replying to LinkedIn posts, and even this has created a world of difference!

4. I read more
If my dad were to write this post, he would recommend Charles Dickensâ€™ books for their vivid characterisation. Now that I read numerous texts for college, I realise reading helps achieve structure, cohesion & fluency in writing.

Like any endeavour, writing is difficult in the start.
Because it is the startâ€” how can it not be?

So I write. Everyday.
